title-group.article-title: Age-dependent changes in the dynamic functional organization of the brain at rest: a cross-cultural replication approach

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Age-associated changes in brain function play an important role in the development of neurodegenerative diseases. Although previous work has examined age-related changes in static functional connectivity, accumulating evidence suggests that advancing age is especially associated with alterations in the dynamic interactions and transitions between different brain states, which hitherto have received less attention. Conclusions of previous studies in this domain are moreover limited by suboptimal replicability of resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and culturally homogenous cohorts. Here, we investigate the robustness of age-associated changes in dynamic functional connectivity (dFC) by capitalizing on the availability of fMRI cohorts from two cultures (Western European and Chinese). In both the LEMON (Western European) and SALD (Chinese) cohorts, we consistently identify two distinct states: a more frequent segregated within-network connectivity state (state I) and a less frequent integrated between-network connectivity state (state II). Moreover, in both these cohorts, older (55–80 years) compared to younger participants (20–35 years) exhibited lower occurrence of and spent less time in state I. Older participants also tended to exhibit more transitions between networks and greater variance in global efficiency. Overall, our cross-cultural replication of age-associated changes in dFC metrics implies that advancing age is robustly associated with a reorganization of dynamic brain activation that favors the use of less functionally specific networks.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As the world population ages, more and more individuals suffer from age-related neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. Understanding how the brain changes with advancing age may therefore provide important insights into neurobiological processes underlying these diseases. Numerous studies have employed functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to examine age-related structural and functional brain changes, as well as their associations with cognitive decline (Betzel et al. 2014; Luo et al. 2020).

With respect to functional organization, functional connectivity (FC)—a commonly used technique that computes pairwise correlations in the blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal between voxels or large-scale networks—has been widely applied to examine age-related changes. Studies in this domain have reported an age-associated reduction in connectivity strength within large-scale networks of the brain, affecting among others the default mode network (DMN), frontoparietal control network (FPCN), salience network, and cognitive executive network (CEN) (Betzel et al. 2014; Geerligs et al. 2015; La et al. 2015; Ng et al. 2016; Mak et al. 2017; Luo et al. 2020; Oschmann and Gawryluk 2020). These findings are paralleled by a relative increase in between-network FC, for example between DMN and FPCN, or DAN (dorsal attention network) and subcortical networks (Geerligs et al. 2015; Ferreira et al. 2016; Zonneveld et al. 2019; Stumme et al. 2020; Das et al. 2021). Results from these and other studies have led to the hypothesis that brain aging may be associated with decreased segregation of functionally distinct networks, thus reflecting a reduction in the specialization of brain networks (Ferreira et al. 2016; Grady et al. 2016; Stumme et al. 2020; Das et al. 2021). Exacerbations of these patterns have been reported in individuals that suffer from Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, suggesting that neurodegenerative processes may accelerate the reduction in functional specialization of brain networks typically seen with normal brain aging (Cai et al. 2020; Cassady et al. 2021).

These previous studies primarily focused on static (i.e. time-invariant) FC methods that calculate spatial correlations over the entire MRI data acquisition of several minutes, whereas they neglect temporal fluctuations in the intrinsic organization of the brain. Increasing evidence indicates that neural activity at rest is highly dynamic. Accordingly, voxel-wise correlations of BOLD connectivity have been reported to fluctuate over the course of an MRI session, taking on distinct configurations that vary from more sparsely connected connectivity states that anatomically overlap with well-defined networks (e.g. CEN, DNM) to highly interconnected states that resemble interactions between these networks (Allen et al. 2014; Preti et al. 2017). Dynamic functional connectivity (dFC) enables the investigation of these time-variant FC patterns and has been increasingly employed in healthy subjects and individuals that suffer from neurologic and psychiatric conditions (Allen et al. 2014; Li et al. 2019; Long et al. 2020; Zhang, Cui, et al. 2021a).

Accumulating evidence suggests that aging is accompanied by changes in dFC patterns (Viviano et al. 2017; Tian et al. 2018; Xia et al. 2019; Zhang, Zhao, et al. 2021b). Xia et al. (2019) found that older individuals exhibited reduced variability in dynamic brain activation, as reflected in decreased switching rates between distinct connectivity patterns. Moreover, Tian et al. (2018) showed that older individuals spent more time in FC states characterized by weaker interactions—interpreted as less efficient information transfer—including less time spent in FC states dominated by within-network connectivity of sensorimotor network and CEN. These studies suggest that age-associated reductions in the differentiation of static FC networks may be the result of more fundamental changes in the dynamic reorganization of and interactions between these networks.

Although these initial studies suggest that dFC is a promising technique that offers insights into mechanisms associated with age-dependent changes in brain function, it is unknown whether its findings are robust to a number of important challenges and confounds. It is increasingly recognized that resting-state fMRI has low replicability (Zuo et al. 2019; Bossier et al. 2020). Whereas replicability issues may be partly attributed to the unconstrained nature of the resting-state paradigm and analytical choices (e.g. sliding window length, head motion parameters, vascular signals) (Allen et al. 2014; Preti et al. 2017), the predominant focus on culturally homogenous samples from Western European cultures also strongly impedes the generalizability of previous findings.

Exposure to environmental risk and resilience factors for age-related cognitive decline is culturally dependent and may account at least partly for the lack of consistent results in this domain across studies (Bittner et al. 2019; Ewers et al. 2021). Important examples include cultural differences in dietary habits over the lifetime and healthcare accessibility for the elderly (Anderson, Druzgal, et al. 2011a; Anderson, Harris, et al. 2011b; Govindaraju et al. 2018; Papanicolas et al. 2021). Ideally, age-associated changes in brain aging should be observable in these differentiated contexts. As a developing country, China differs from European countries in dietary habits, incomes, and healthcare systems. Age-related dFC changes that are invariant to these cultural/social differences would represent promising candidates for generalizable indices or even biomarkers of brain aging (Zhang et al. 2015; Fang et al. 2020). Importantly, cross-cultural replication studies have been suggested as a promising avenue to improve the generalizability and replicability of age-related changes in fMRI metrics (Montag 2018; Sheng et al. 2022), although, unfortunately, well-powered cross-cultural fMRI datasets that are stringently matched on important methodological variables (e.g. acquisition protocol, scanner type, magnet strength) remain scarce to date. Nevertheless, initial steps towards truly cross-cultural replication attempts might be made by capitalizing on recent increases in the number of publicly available fMRI data repositories.

In the current study, we assessed the cross-cultural robustness of dFC to identify age-related changes in dynamic brain connectivity. Specifically, we analyzed resting-state fMRI data from two independent and comparably large samples in Europe and China (LEMON: Leipzig Study for Mind-Body-Emotion Interaction Dataset—Germany and SALD: Southwest University Adult Lifespan Dataset—China) to obtain commonly used dFC outcome measures after strictly controlling for methodological confounds. Our specific goals were to investigate whether age-related changes in (i) temporal properties of dFC (fraction time, mean dwell time, and the number of transitions between distinct states) and (ii) dynamic topological organization of functionally connected networks (i.e. global and local efficiency variance) (Kim et al. 2017; Xia et al. 2019) could be observed in both cohorts, which would suggest a degree of robustness across differentiated contexts.

sec.title: Primary cohort
sec.p: As a primary cohort, we selected the LEMON (http://fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/retro/MPI_LEMON.html) study (Babayan et al. 2019). This dataset comprised 228 native German adults, which included both healthy participants and participants with (current) psychiatric or neurological disorders. Given the sensitivity of dFC to head motion (Preti et al. 2017), we employed stringent head motion criteria (max. head motion >3 mm translational, >3° rotation; n = 3). We additionally excluded participants (i) that were taking psychoactive drugs (urine drug screening and semi-structured interview for buprenorphine, amphetamines, benzodiazepines, cocaine, methamphetamine, morphine/heroine, methadone, and marihuana; n = 19), (ii) with neurological disorders (DSM-5 diagnosis; n = 28) and/or alcohol abuse and family history of alcohol addiction (DSM-5 diagnosis and semi-structured interview; n = 53), (iii) with failed spatial normalization as identified by visual inspection (n = 2), and (iv) with missing demographic and/or MRI data (n = 8). After applying these criteria, a total of 133 participants remained. In line with previous studies (Doucet et al. 2021), and to investigate age-associated changes in dFC metrics, subjects from both datasets were subdivided into young and older groups (young: n = 88, age range = 20–35, male/female = 57/31; older: n = 45, age range = 55–80, male/female = 22/23). All participants provided written informed consent. The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Medical Faculty at the University of Leipzig, Germany.

sec.title: Cross-cultural replication cohort
sec.p: As a cross-cultural replication sample, we used the publicly accessible Southwest University Adult Lifespan Dataset (SALD; http://fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/retro/sald.html) resting-state fMRI dataset consisting of 494 healthy native Chinese adults (Wei et al. 2018). In this dataset, participants with a (current) psychiatric and/or neurological disorder and/or the use of psychotropic drugs within 3 months of the MRI scan were deemed ineligible (and were therefore not included in the dataset). We excluded 163 participants based on head motion (max. head motion >3 mm translation, >3° rotation; n = 16), failed spatial normalization as defined by visual inspection (n = 21), ages that fell outside of the age ranges of the young and older LEMON participants (n = 127), and missing fMRI data (n = 1). Please note that some participants fit multiple exclusion criteria: the numbers reported here therefore reflect the number of participants that met each exclusion criterion. Three hundred thirty subjects were included for further data analysis (young: n = 168, age range = 20–35, male/female = 68/100; older: n = 162, age range = 55–80, male/female = 66/96). All participants provided written informed consent. The study was approved by the Research Ethics Committee of the Brain Center of Southwest University.

sec.title: Primary cohort
sec.p: MRI data were collected on a 3 Tesla MRI system (MAGNETOM Verio, Siemens Healthcare GmbH, Erlangen, Germany) equipped with a 32-channel head coil. Structural T1-weighted images were acquired using a magnetization-prepared 2 rapid acquisition gradient echo (MP2RAGE) (Marques et al. 2010) sequence (repetition time [TR] = 5,000 ms, echo time [TE] = 2.92 ms, flip angle [FA] 1 = 4°, FA 2 = 5°, field of view [FOV] = 256 mm, voxel size = 1 × 1 × 1 mm). Resting-state data were acquired using a T2*-weighted echo planar imaging (EPI) sequence with the following parameters: TR = 1,400 ms, TE = 30 ms, FA = 69°, FOV = 202 mm, voxel size =2.3 × 2.3 × 2.3 mm, slice thickness = 2.3 mm, image matrix = 88 × 88. The resting state scan duration in this cohort was 15 min 30s. During the scan, participants were asked to keep their eyes open and to remain awake while looking at a low-contrast fixation cross.

sec.title: Cross-cultural replication sample (validation cohort)
sec.p: All SALD MRI data were collected on a 3 Tesla MRI system (Siemens Magnetom Trio, Siemens Medical, Erlangen, Germany) equipped with a 16-channel whole-brain coil. Structural data were acquired using a magnetization-prepared rapid gradient echo (MPRAGE) sequence (TR = 1,900 ms, TE =2.52 ms, FA =9°, FOV =176, and voxel size = 1 × 1 × 1 mm). FMRI data were acquired using a gradient echo planar image (GRE-EPI) sequence (TR = 2,000 ms, TE = 30 ms, FA = 90°, FOV = 220 mm, voxel size = 3.4 × 3.4 × 4 mm, slice thickness = 3 mm, image matrix = 64 × 64). The total acquisition time was 8 min 4 s (242 volumes). Participants were instructed to remain awake with their eyes closed and to rest without thinking of anything. The SALD team excluded participants who fell asleep during the scan.

sec.title: MRI data preprocessing
sec.p: All resting-state fMRI data were preprocessed in a combined SPM12 (http://www.fil.ion.ac.uk/spm/; Wellcome Trust Centre for Neuroimaging) and DPABI (Version: V4.3_200401; http://rfmri.org/dpabi) (Yan et al. 2016) analysis pipeline. We discarded the first 5 volumes to ensure MRI signal equilibrium. Since scan duration can influence resting-state connectivity estimates (Birn et al. 2013), we discarded the last 312 volumes of resting-state data for participants in the LEMON dataset, resulting in a scan duration (7 min 56 s, 340 volumes) that was nearly identical to the scan duration of the SALD dataset (note: we repeated our dFC analyses using the entire time series, see Temporal properties section). Next, all images were corrected for head motion, spatial normalization using the Diffeomorphic Anatomical Registration Through Exponentiated Lie Algebra (DARTEL) template, after which the resulting images were smoothed (6 mm full-width at half-maximum Gaussian kernel). We discuss band-pass filtering as part of the dFC procedures reported below (see Computation of dFC section).

Comparing head motion as defined by framewise displacements (Jenkinson et al. 2002), we observed a significant difference between the young and older groups in the LEMON (young: mean ± SD = 0.11 ± 0.03; older: mean ± SD = 0.18 ± 0.08; P < 0.001, two-sample T-test) and SALD dataset (young: mean ± SD = 0.08 ± 0.04; older: mean ± SD = 0.15 ± 0.07; P < 0.001, two-sample T-test). We therefore included 24 motion parameters (6 motion parameters of the current volume and the preceding volume, plus each of these values squared) for each participant. Since global signal regression can introduce spurious anti-correlations which may reduce the sensitivity of dFC (Murphy et al. 2009; Anderson, Druzgal, et al. 2011a; Anderson, Harris, et al. 2011b; Saad et al. 2012), we used a component-based noise reduction method (CompCor: 5 principal components) to remove noise from white matter (WM), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), global signal, and other sources of physiological noise (Behzadi et al. 2007; Chai et al. 2012). CompCor is a commonly used technique (Kim et al. 2017; Díez-Cirarda et al. 2018) that is thought to have greater specificity and sensitivity for positive correlations (compared to, e.g. global signal regression), as well as a lower risk of artificially introducing anticorrelations into FC estimations.

sec.title: Group independent component analysis
sec.p: Next, group-level ICA was performed using the Group ICA Of fMRI Toolbox (GIFT) (http://icatb.sourceforge.net/) (Calhoun et al. 2001) with the aim of identifying networks of interest. Before performing data reduction, voxel-wise variance normalization steps were applied as recommended by Allen et al. (2011), which is useful for high-dimensionality reduction (Beckmann and Smith 2004). For subject-specific data reduction, a total of 120 principal components were retained using principal component analysis. For the group-level data reduction, the concatenated (reduced) subject-level data were decomposed into 100 group independent components (ICs) using the expectation maximization algorithm. The Infomax ICA algorithm was repeated 20 times in ICASSO (http://www.cis.hut.fi/projects/ica/icasso) to improve stability (Himberg et al. 2004). Components with an average intra-cluster similarity value >0.8 were retained (Kim et al. 2017). To obtain subject-specific spatial maps and time courses for each IC, group ICs were backprojected using the GICA back reconstruction algorithm (Calhoun et al. 2001). Spatial maps and time courses of components were not scale since we opted for a variance normalization method during data preprocessing (Calhoun et al. 2001).

Of the 100 ICs, 51 and 43 ICs—for the LEMON and SALD datasets, respectively—were selected according to Allen’s criteria (Allen et al. 2014) based on consensus between 3 independent evaluators (XY, XZ, and FX). Components were identified based on the principles that (i) IC peak coordinates of spatial maps were primarily in gray matter and showed low spatial overlap with vascular, ventricular, motion, and other artifacts; (ii) time courses were dominated by low-frequency fluctuations (ratio power < 0.10 Hz to 0.15–0.25 Hz); and (iii) time courses were characterized by a high dynamic range (dynamic range >0.02). Based on those criteria, we additionally calculated spatial correlations between ICs and template to reidentify significant components (correlation coefficient >0.2) (Du et al. 2020).

sec.title: Computation of dFC
sec.p: DFC was estimated using the GIFT toolbox via 2 steps: (i) a sliding window approach (i.e. changes in FC over time) and (ii) K-means clustering (i.e. recurrence of FC activity patterns). Resting-state time series were divided into bins of 40/28 TRs (LEMON: 40*1.4 = 56 s; SALD: 28*2 = 56 s) with sigma 3-TR of Gaussian, and a 1 TR step between windows. Additional processing steps were applied to improve the signal-to-noise ratio and remove physiological confounders. Those steps included detrending (linear, cubic, and quadratic), regression of motion parameters and physiological noise including WM, CSF, and other physiological noises (total of 29 regressors), despiking using 3DDESPIKE and low-pass filtering using a high-frequency cutoff of 0.15 Hz.

Next, we applied a K-means clustering algorithm to identify the number of distinct brain states (Lloyd 1982). Time series correlation matrices were used to estimate reoccurring FC. We used the L1 distance (Manhattan distance) function to estimate the similarity between windowed FC matrices (Aggarwal et al. 2001). The K-means algorithm was repeated 100 times to reduce the bias of initial random selection of cluster centroids (Kim et al. 2017). Moreover, windows consisting of local maxima in FC variance were used as subsamples for each participant to decrease redundancy and computational demands.

According to previous literature on brain aging (Kim et al. 2017; Fiorenzato et al. 2019) and cluster number validity analyses (Silhouette criterion; Rousseeuw 1987), we set the optimal number of clusters (k) to 2. In line with K-means results, each participant’s dFC matrices were then categorized into one of the two clusters—or, states—based on their similarity to the cluster centroids. We also used Bayesian information (Warnick et al. 2018) and Elbow criterion (Allen et al. 2014), two additional commonly used clustering approaches, to validate the robustness of our results. These criteria revealed a slightly different number of distinct brain states (k = 3: Bayesian information criteria; k = 4: Elbow criteria), and we repeated key analyses using these cluster solutions (see Temporal properties section).

We extracted three commonly used temporal properties of each dFC state: (i) fraction time (i.e. the percentage of time spent in each state), (ii) mean dwell time (state duration, i.e. the number of consecutive windows in a particular state before transferring to another state), and (iii) the number of transitions (i.e. how many times a switch between states occurred). The fraction, mean dwell time, and the number of transitions of the young and older groups were calculated using Wilcoxon rank-sum test.

sec.title: Dynamic topological metrics: global and local efficiency difference between 2 groups
sec.p: We used GRETNA (http:/www.nitrc.org/projects/Gretna) to obtain topological properties of the resting-state fMRI data. Brain aging is thought to affect two key graph metrics that control network efficiency: global and local efficiency (Kim et al. 2017; Xia et al. 2019). Global network efficiency was defined as the average efficiency across all node pairs, representing parallel information transfer in the network. In comparison, local efficiency was defined as the average of nodal local efficiency within neighbors of a node, which is thought to represent communication among neighbors.

LEMON and SALD ICs were defined as nodes and the FC between components as edges for each time window. Subject-specific FC matrices were then binarized with respect to sparsity threshold (i.e. the number of actual edges divided by the maximum possible number of edges). The sparsity threshold was defined as 0.1–0.34 in 0.01 increments to maximize the reliability of the global and local efficiency estimation. In line with previous work (Kim et al. 2017), only positive correlations were included in this study. Next, we obtained the global and local efficiency at each sparsity threshold. We applied an area under the curve approach to avoid the selection of an arbitrary threshold (Kim et al. 2017; Navalpotro-Gomez et al. 2020; Xu et al. 2021). Finally, as suggested by Kim et al. (2017), we calculated the variance of the global and local efficiency over time to examine age-associated differences in dynamic graph properties and compared young and older participants on these metrics using Wilcoxon rank-sum tests.
For a visual representation of the data analysis pipeline described above, we refer the reader to Supplementary Fig. 1.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All results reported below were obtained using the entire sample of participants after the removal of exclusions according to the criteria described in the Participants section (final sample: n LEMON = 133, n SALD = 330).

sec.title: Sample descriptive
sec.p: The demographics of each sample are reported in Table 1. We observed no significant sex differences between young and older participants in either dataset, although older participants in the LEMON and SALD cohorts exhibited more head motion (Table 1 for all relevant statistics).

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: aThe LEMON dataset only contained age ranges. bTwo-sample T-test. cChi-square test. Data are given as mean ± SD. LEMON, Leipzig Study for Mind-Body-Emotion Interaction Dataset; SALD, Southwest University Adult Lifespan Dataset.

sec.title: Brain network identity in the discovery cohort (LEMON)
sec.p: The spatial maps of 51 ICs were identified using group ICA. We classified these components as belonging to 1 of 7 networks: AU (auditory network: 2 ICs—component 13, 65), SM (sensorimotor network: 9 ICs—component 1, 2, 3, 4, 11, 16, 46, 64, 77), VI (visual network: 11 ICs—component 22, 25, 29, 33, 34, 38, 44, 69, 76, 84, 97), CEN ( 18 ICs—component 17, 27, 28, 40, 42, 55, 57, 62, 67, 71, 73, 78, 79, 81, 86, 91, 95, 98), DMN (4 ICs—component 18, 36, 51, 89), BG (basal ganglia network: 5 ICs—component 6, 7, 9, 20, 87), CB (cerebellar network: 2 ICs component—50, 68). Spatial maps containing ICs and static between-network FC matrices are presented in Fig. 1 (top row). More information regarding the location and statistics of ICs are presented in Supplementary Table 1.

caption.p: Independent components (ICs) identified by group ICA. A) Leipzig Study for Mind-Body-Emotion Interaction Dataset (LEMON)/discovery cohort (top row)—51 observed ICs across 7 networks. B) Static functional connectivity (FC) matrices for all 51 components. C) Southwest University Adult Lifespan Dataset (SALD)/replication cohort (bottom row)—43 observed ICs across 7 networks. D) Static FC matrices for all 43 components. Note: The relationship between color and network (in panels A and C) is available in Supplementary Table 1 and 2.

sec.title: Brain network identity in the replication cohort (SALD)
sec.p: The spatial maps of 43 ICs in the SALD dataset were similarly assigned to 1 of 7 networks: AU ( 3 ICs—component 58, 71, 98), SM (9 ICs—component 3, 5, 11, 12, 44, 45, 64, 75, 80), VI (8 ICs—component 17, 20, 29, 33, 42, 46, 62, 91), CEN: ( 15 ICs—component 30, 34, 50, 55, 56, 59, 61, 67, 70,73, 76, 78, 79, 86, 92), DMN (6 ICs—component 8, 14, 21, 38, 54, 60), BG ( 1 IC—component 19), and CB ( 1 IC—component 13) (see Fig. 1 bottom row for visualization and Supplementary Table 2 for location/statistics).

sec.title: Age-dependent dFC changes are mostly replicable across cultures
Clustering analysis and FC strength in dynamic states
sec.p: Discovery cohort: Using K-means clustering, we uncovered two distinct functional brain states: (i) a more frequent and relatively sparsely connected state (state I; 74% of scan time), characterized by positive within-network correlations in SM, VI, and DMN, and (ii) a less frequent between-network connected state (state II; 26% of scan time), characterized both by positive correlations between SM and VI, and negative between-network correlations involving SM and VI (e.g. with DMN, CB) (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Dynamic functional connectivity (dFC) brain states for Leipzig Study for Mind-Body-Emotion Interaction (LEMON) Dataset. A) The total number of occurrences and percentage of total occurrences are listed at the top of each figure. B) FC matrix for each state.

sec.p: Replication cohort: Similar to the LEMON dataset, we observed a more frequent (62%) relatively sparsely connected state characterized by a positive within-network correlation in SM, VI, CEN, and DMN (state I; 62% of scan time) and a less frequent but strongly between-network connected state (state II; 38% of scan time), characterized by positive correlations between SM and VI, and negative between-network correlation involving SM and AU (Fig. 3). A correlation matrix of between-state differences for each dataset is available in Supplementary Fig. 2.

caption.p: Dynamic functional connectivity (dFC) brain states for Southwest University Adult Lifespan Dataset (SALD). A) The total number of occurrences and percentage of total occurrences are listed at the top of each figure. B) FC matrix for each state.

sec.title: Temporal properties
sec.p: Discovery cohort: Comparing young and older individuals, we observed significant differences in fraction time for both states (state I: young: 79.19 ± 27.12%, older: 65.23 ± 31.35%, z = 2.56, P = 0.010, Cohen’s d = 0.46; state II: young: 20.81 ± 27.12%, older: 34.77 ± 31.35%, z = −2.56, P = 0.010, Cohen’s d = −0.46, Wilcoxon rank-sum test), suggesting an average 13.96% decrease/increase in state I/II in older participants. Older compared to young participants additionally exhibited significantly shorter dwell time in state I (young: 164.19 ± 98.31, older: 116.12 ± 96.67, z = 2.82, P = 0.004, Cohen’s d = 0.50, Wilcoxon rank-sum test) and higher dwell times in state II (young: 36.05 ± 50.72, older: 53.60 ± 59.63, z = −1.98, P = 0.048, Cohen’s d = 0.35, Wilcoxon rank-sum test). Lastly, older compared to young participants more frequently switched between distinct brain states (young: 1.86 ± 1.85, older: 2.58 ± 1.78, z = −2.55, P = 0.011, Cohen’s d = 0.45, Wilcoxon rank-sum test), suggesting a reduction in the temporal stability of brain states in older participants (see Fig. 4 top row).

caption.p: Age-dependent changes in the temporal properties of dynamic functional connectivity (dFC) (fraction time; mean dwell time; number of transitions). A) Leipzig Study for Mind-Body-Emotion Interaction (LEMON) Dataset (top row). B) Southwest University Adult Lifespan Dataset (SALD) (bottom row). (#: 0.05–0.1; *P < 0.05; **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001).

sec.p: Replication cohort: With respect to the key outcome dFC measures that differed between young and older SALD participants, we replicated most observations in the LEMON dataset. That is, older participants spent less time in state I and more time in state II (state I: young: 65.75 ± 22.94%, older: 57.57 ± 27.79%, z = 2.70, P = 0.007, Cohen’s d = 0.30; state II: young: 34.25 ± 22.94%, older: 42.43 ± 27.79%, z = −2.70, P = 0.007, Cohen’s d = −0.30, Wilcoxon rank-sum test; an average 8.18% decrease/increase in state I/II in older participants). Older participants also had significantly shorter dwell times in state I (young: 65.23 ± 52.42, older: 57.82 ± 55.39, z = 2.77, P = 0.006, Cohen’s d = 0.31, Wilcoxon rank-sum test), and a marginally longer dwell time in state II (young: 30.35 ± 25.51, older: 38.43 ± 38.43, z = −1.79, P = 0.073, Cohen’s d = 0.20). Older and young participants, however, did not differ in number of state transitions (young: 3.83 ± 2.21, older: 3.94 ± 2.34, z = −0.63, P = 0.528, Cohen’s d = 0.07, Wilcoxon rank-sum test) although, numerically, the direction of brain state transitions in older individuals matched with observations from the LEMON dataset (see Fig. 4 bottom row). We obtained highly similar results when repeating our analyses using the entire time series, different window lengths, and when using different clustering methods (see Supplementary Results 1, 2, and 3).

sec.title: Topological properties
sec.p: Discovery cohort: We observed a significant difference in global efficiency variance between young and older participants, with older participants showing higher global efficiency variance (young: 6.26 × 10−5 ± 7.47 × 10−5, older: 7.26 × 10−5 ± 4.88 × 10−5, z = −2.30, P = 0.021, Cohen’s d = 0.41, Wilcoxon rank-sum test). When excluding outliers with values ±3 SD above the group mean, the 2 groups still differed on global efficiency variance (young: 5.09 × 10−5 ± 3.85 × 10−5, older: 7.26 × 10−5 ± 4.88 × 10−5, z = −2.70, P = 0.007, Cohen’s d = 0.48, outliers = 3). However, significant group differences in local efficiency variance were not observed (excluding ±3 SD outliers: young: 6.21 × 10−5 ± 2.95 × 10−5, older: 6.21 × 10−5 ± 2.66 × 10−5, z = −0.05, P = 0.956, Cohen’s d = 0.009; including ±3 SD outlier: young: 6.09 × 10−5 ± 2.74 × 10−5, older: 6.21 × 10−5 ± 2.66 × 10−5, z = −0.05, P = 0.870, Cohen’s d = 0.006, outliers = 1) (Fig. 5A).

caption.p: Age-dependent changes in dynamic topological properties (variance of global and local efficiency). A) Leipzig Study for Mind-Body-Emotion Interaction (LEMON) (left) Dataset. B) Southwest University Adult Lifespan Dataset (SALD) (right). (*P < 0.05; ***P < 0.001).

sec.p: Replication cohort: Older compared to young participants exhibited higher global efficiency variance (young: 5.68 × 10−5 ± 4.74 × 10−5, older: 9.12 × 10−5 ± 7.29 × 10−5, z = −5.90, P < 0.001, Cohen’s d = 0.69) and local efficiency variance (young: 4.83 × 10−5 ± 2.18 × 10−5, older: 8.66 × 10−5 ± 4.16 × 10−5, z = −9.39, P < 0.001, Cohen’s d = 1.29). These results were not affected by outliers with extreme (± 3SD) global/local efficiency variance values (global efficiency variance: young: 5.68 × 10−5 ± 4.74 × 10−5, older: 8.28 × 10−5 ± 5.46 × 10−5, z = −5.53, P < 0.001, Cohen’s d = 0.64, outliers = 5; local efficiency variance: young: 4.83 × 10−5 ± 2.18 × 10−5, older: 8.30 × 10−5 ± 3.68 × 10−5, z = −9.11, P < 0.001, Cohen’s d = 1.16, outliers = 5, Wilcoxon rank-sum test) (Fig. 5B). An overview of (non-)replicated results is provided in Table 2.

caption.p: Overview of age-associated changes in dFC metrics in the discovery and replication cohorts.

tr.td: Age-associated increases in fraction time in the between-network connectivity state
Age-associated increases in mean dwell time in the between-network connectivity state
Observed only in the discovery cohort
Age-associated increases in brain state transitions
Age-associated increases in global efficiency variance
Observed only in the replication cohort
Age-associated increases in local efficiency variance

sec.p: To allow comparisons to previous FC studies, we additionally calculated static global and local efficiency metrics. In group comparisons, we observed only that static global efficiency was robustly greater in young compared to older participants (Supplementary Results 4). These results suggest that advancing age is associated with greater global efficiency variance and lower static global efficiency.
Finally, we observed no main effects of sex on any of the temporal and topological properties discussed above in either dataset and age group (all P > 0.07).

sec.title: Comparing age-associated changes in temporal and topological properties between datasets
sec.p: Although the LEMON and SALD datasets differ from each other on important methodological details (e.g. scanner type, acquisition protocol, resting state scan duration), we did conduct exploratory dataset (LEMON, SALD) by age group (young, older participants) interaction analyses to more formally investigate if the magnitude of age-associated changes in dFC temporal and topological properties differed between datasets (see Supplemental Results 5 for detailed results). Briefly, these analyses only revealed significant dataset-by-age group interactions for the mean dwell time in state I (age-associated change LEMON>SALD) and local efficiency variance (age-associated change SALD>LEMON).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We conducted a first cross-cultural replication study of age-dependent dFC changes in two independent samples, with the aim of assessing the robustness of dynamic functional brain changes associated with aging. In both the discovery and replication cohorts, we found evidence for two distinct brain states: a dominant state characterized primarily by dense positive connectivity patterns within well-characterized functionally distinct networks (e.g. CEN, DMN), as well as a less frequent pattern of high interconnectivity between these networks. Importantly, in both the LEMON and SALD datasets, most temporal properties of these distinct connectivity states differed with age, such that young individuals displayed higher fraction time and longer mean dwell time in the more frequent within-network connectivity state. In contrast, fraction and mean dwell time in the less functionally specific between-network connectivity state were greater for older participants. Older individuals moreover exhibited greater variance in global efficiency. Together, these observations yield two important insights. Firstly, our results confirm that healthy aging is associated with a reorganization of dynamic brain activation, such that connectivity patterns that favor functional specificity are traded in for less efficient, whole-brain, connectivity patterns. Secondly, we demonstrate that these age-dependent group differences in dFC metrics are observable across samples with presumably different exposure to socio-cultural factors and healthcare access (although see our discussion below). Of note, our results were also mostly robust against variations in scan duration, window lengths, and clustering methods, suggesting that they are unlikely to be the result of analytical idiosyncrasies.

Regarding the age-associated changes in temporal properties of connectivity states, we observed that older participants exhibited reduced reliance on segregated, functionally specialized, brain networks at rest. Numerous previous studies have reported that healthy older individuals exhibit alterations in FC, both within well-defined higher-order cognitive networks (i.e. DMN, CEN) and primary processing networks (i.e. VI and SM) (Hafkemeijer et al. 2012; Tomasi and Volkow 2012; Chan et al. 2014; Lim et al. 2014; Damoiseaux 2017; Cassady et al. 2019; Zonneveld et al. 2019; Oschmann and Gawryluk 2020). One way to interpret these age-associated changes in network configurations is as a compensatory mechanism. For example, the STACr model (The Scaffolding Theory of Aging and Cognitive revised) posits that adverse effects on functional and structural brain processes can be ameliorated by “compensatory scaffolding” (Reuter-Lorenz and Park 2014). Our results fit well with this framework, which views reliance on between-network connectivity patterns as a compensatory mechanism that preserves cognitive functions at old age. Although speculative, age-associated compensatory mechanisms in our sample could be reflected by increased/decreased fraction time and mean dwell time in the between/within-network connectivity state.

We additionally observed robust group differences in dynamic whole-brain topology measures that largely replicated across cultural backgrounds. Previous studies have demonstrated an overall decline in global and local efficiency, derived from static FC analyses, in older compared to younger adults (Gomez-Ramirez et al. 2015; Iordan et al. 2017; Varangis et al. 2019; Xia et al. 2019). However, to our knowledge, no previous studies have investigated age-dependent variability in the topological organization, obtained using dFC. Compared to their young counterparts, older participants showed significantly greater global efficiency variability in both datasets. Moreover, consistent with previous studies, we also found older participants to exhibit lower static global efficiency across the two datasets. Global efficiency metrics are thought to capture parallel information transfer and integrated processing, which correlate positively with IQ and cognitive abilities (Bullmore and Sporns 2012). Thus, greater age-associated variability in global efficiency and, correspondingly, less static global efficiency suggests that less time spent in brain states dominated by functionally distinct networks may result in more unstable, and thus less efficient, parallel information transfer (Bullmore and Sporns 2012; Kim et al. 2017).

It has been hypothesized that culturally specific factors (e.g. dietary habits, exposure to distinct risk factors, healthcare quality and accessibility) may influence the progression of neurodegenerative diseases and cognitive decline more generally (Rodriguez et al. 2022; Sheng et al. 2022). However, previous dFC studies have mainly been conducted on culturally homogenous samples (Viviano et al. 2017; Tian et al. 2018; Xia et al. 2019; Zhang, Zhao, et al. 2021b), raising doubts about the universality of age-related dFC changes. This cross-culture dFC fMRI study shows broad similarities across cultures in terms of dFC temporal and topological properties of older participants. Specifically, our analyses reveal a relatively consistent picture, independent of cultural background and analytical choices, of age-associated changes in temporal and topological dFC properties that hint at increased reliance on less functionally specialized and less efficient neural networks in healthy older participants. It is worth noting that our exploratory direct comparisons between datasets suggest that the magnitude of some age-related dFC metrics may differ between samples, although as of yet, we cannot accurately interpret these results due to important scanner type, acquisition protocol, scan duration, and sample size differences. Taken together, this work suggests that dFC metrics, especially fraction time, dwell time, and global efficiency variance, may be promising and generalizable neural indices for brain changes in older healthy and pathological populations.

Regarding the latter population, Parkinson’s and associated diseases (i.e. Parkinson’s disease mild cognitive impairment—PDM; Parkinson’s disease dementia—PDD) are characterized by altered temporal properties in dynamic connectivity (Kim et al. 2017; Díez-Cirarda et al. 2018; Fiorenzato et al. 2019; Xu et al. 2021). Previous work found decreased mean dwell time in segregated within-network connectivity states and increased brain state transitions in PD and PDM compared to matched control participants (Kim et al. 2017; Díez-Cirarda et al. 2018). PDD, however, exhibited longer dwell time in segregated within-network connectivity states, in combination with fewer brain state transitions (Fiorenzato et al. 2019). These results underscore the potential of dFC’s sensitivity to distinct neurodegenerative states.

Our cross-cultural neuroimaging replication approach also comes with some limitations. Firstly, participant numbers in the young and older participant groups in the LEMON dataset were unbalanced (i.e., young>older participants in the final analysis sample) due to the use of more stringent exclusion criteria that are known to impact resting state and dFC metrics (e.g. motion). Secondly, the two datasets did not include the same cognitive variables, thus hampering the investigation of relationships between dFC changes and cognitive abilities. Future harmonized cross-cultural studies should aim to include identical cognitive assessments. Thirdly, the sliding window technique has limitations inherent to the methodology, such as the effect of window lengths on the results (Preti et al. 2017), which we aimed to minimize by relying on previously suggested window lengths. Fourth, we did not have access to a substantial group of middle-aged participants (36–54 years old) in the LEMON dataset and therefore were unable to explore dFC changes across the lifespan. Fifth, our study investigated whole-brain dFC changes, instead of relying on a priori specified networks. Additional insights may be gained by focusing on dFC metrics in networks previously implicated in (e.g. compensatory or vulnerability-related) age-associated changes. Sixth, the mismatch in important variables (i.e. scanner type, acquisition protocol, sample sizes) prevents us from making meaningful direct comparisons between datasets. Therefore, in the future, stringently harmonized cross-cultural datasets are essential to shed light on the magnitude of age-associated changes in differentiated contexts. Seventh, as of yet, the specific molecular drivers responsible for age-associated changes in fMRI metrics remain unknown, although these may include oxidative stress, metabolic alterations, or inflammation (Ridderinkhof and Krugers 2022). Future cross-cultural comparisons of such mechanisms may provide important mechanistic insights into (differences in) biological processes that facilitate age-associated neural changes measured indirectly with fMRI.

Finally, both datasets used different eyes closed/open instructions during the resting-state scan. Previous work has indicated that eyes closed/open instructions affect FC estimates. For example, different instructions have been shown to impact VI–SM and VI–AU connectivity strength (Agcaoglu et al. 2019). Interestingly, in both datasets, we observed age-associated differences in most dFC metrics despite the difference in eyes open/closed instructions, perhaps suggesting a degree of robustness, although such effects need to be investigated more systematically in future studies.

Taken together, this work provides novel insights into age-associated changes in dynamic neural processes in samples with different cultural backgrounds. Our work suggests that dynamic temporal (e.g. fraction time, dwell time) and topological (e.g. global efficiency variance) properties are robustly altered with advancing age, hinting at the idea that such metrics may represent important functional correlates of brain aging.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the China MOST2030 Brain Project (Grant No. 2022ZD0208500) and the China Scholarship Council (CSC) (Grant No. 202006070007).

Conflict of interest statement: DH has received financial compensation as a consultant for P1vitalProducts Ltd. These activities were unrelated to the work presented in this manuscript. The authors declare no competing interests.

sec.title: Data and materials availability
sec.p: All fMRI data included in this study are publicly available (LEMON dataset: http://fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/retro/MPI_LEMON.html) and (SALD dataset: http://fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/retro/sald.html). The dFC results of the current study have been uploaded to the Open Science Framework (https://osf.io/xenpc/).

sec.title: Author contributions
sec.p: XY and XZ designed this study. XY performed data analysis with the help of XZ, DH, BB, DL, and FX. Interpretation of data and drafting of the manuscript were done by XY, DH, BB, and DL. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.
